bibl.title: Letter from Atcheson Laughlin Hench to Philip Showalter Hench, October 21, 1940

div1.p: Atcheson Hench regrets that he will miss the Washington and Jefferson College ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Atcheson Laughlin Hench to Philip Showalter Hench, October 21, 1940
div1.p:
Some weeks ago I had a notion that maybe I
could get to W & J., especially when Uncle Sam suggested that
we drive up together late Friday so that we could be there for the
Saturday exercises. But about a week ago I could see
that I couldn't go. I have, for one thing, a formal lecture
that I am giving on Monday afternoon, probably the most
dignified and serious speech Ive made, and it's still in
the formative stage. And there are many other things. Recently
I was made chairman of the Public Occasions Committee (speeches,
foundation lectureships, etc.) and that is a time- consuming
job too. So I shall have to miss the trip. I'm sorry: Id
like to listen in on it all, but I cannot.

I didn't saywrite anything about Mr. Moran for there was
nothing I could learn to say. Within the last 10 days. When I saw,
Jordan, he said they still were waiting for news. Nor till
four days ago did I hear anything and that was the
medical school's invitation to the banquet for Moran up
at Mr. Beauchamps new mountain top dining room,
banquet hall, I should say. It's to be held tomorrow,
Tuesday night. So he can easily make the jump
to Washington and be on hand for everything there.

I'll ask Dr. Jordan about Dr. Cooke and see if
some one who understands medicine will take make some
memorandum of what Cooke says, if, and, and when
he says what.

It's nearly time for the last mail out. But I'll
tell you a joke I heard the other day. A man had been away
from city life for a long time, and when he returned he was
asked to a rather swell dinner. He was fearful less
his manners might have be not all they are supposed
to be. Still, he went. Later a friend asked him how
he got along. “All right, for a good deal of the meal,”
he answered, “except for one thing. When they asked me if
I wanted some corn, I passed my glass instead
of my plate.”
